bibl.title: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to [Emma Coleman Carter], [18--]

div1.p: Carter writes about the Public Health Service, his children, and his health.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to [Emma Coleman Carter], [18--]
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798
U.S.
1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of__________, Surgeon's Office,
__________, 18.
div1.p:

treated in the Marine-Hospital until one can be
built on Ellis Island the U. S. Immigration landing.
The N. Y. Commissioners were so corrupt & there was so little, or
rather no, confidence in them in the West where most
of the immigrants go. that the U. S. was well nigh compel-
led to take charge. Whether they will do any better remains
to be seen. Our men will as they are not political-appointees.
I don't exactly see why we had to get into it, it is an
onerous service, & no extra pay; but I suppose because we
are the only medical bureau with a lot of miscel-
laneous functions & under the Treasury.

Also a new bill for “Inter state Quarantine” (due to
the Fla. yellow fever?) passed in April that pos-
sibly adds to our efficiency but certainly does to
our duties & as little as I like Maritime Quar-
antine I should like the Inland still less.

I think the service was far pleasanter to its officers when it was
merely a Hospital Service still every one must feel a certain
gratification in serving an increase of usefulness
in his corps & I believe the main reasons of extension of
function are (1) we have less (1/10 as much) “red tape” onthan the Army
or Navy & are easier to get started: (2) a clause which forbids any increase of Compen-
sation or receipt of any fee. (3) (I hope) efficiency of previous
work. But I must say we have some men who are
not worth their salt; two resigned (under compact this
spring. I think the younger men average better than the older ones.
Henry was improved by his trip to Biloxi: eats better etc. The
others are well, save my Jan.

We are not quite as ready for Q. as I could wish, an account of the weath-
er, but ready enough to get along & if I can get one week free it
will do very well. Love to all at N. R. & in Ashland
How are you & the boys getting as the weather gets warmer?
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate son H. R. Carter Monday afternoon,
Face better decidedly better but averages bad, I will not have the
dead bone & outside abcess wh' sometimes came & it may be that the
alveolar process will separate as a whole instead of absorbing as it sh'd
(night.) The heaviest sudden squall I ever saw came this afternoon & drove the
Annie ashore- she is unhurt but is on bare ground draws 3 feet & we
will have trouble getting her off. & will not be able to go over tomorrow,
I order (from Louisville) $1.00 of roses for Hugh by this mail. Don't put them
where water will stand on the roots. Put the Marichal Niel in the most
favored place. as it is delicate for one year. it is a climber. (Except La France &
Catherine Mermet. which are dwarfs almost. the others are bush roses of good
growth.
Hugh had best set the roses in a little bed about 18 inches a-
part until fall when they should be good sized but shes & he
can can move them
